sentences.text: To round off this module, we're going to look at the midcourt.
The midcourt is often overlooked, but skilled players are able to generate a lot of pressure from this area.
As usual, good footwork is key to doing this.
You'll be jumping out to intercept flat lifts, as well as straining loads to retrieve difficult smashes.
Now, before we get started, I want to emphasise that speed is incredibly important for these mid court shots.
Obviously, we always want to be quick when moving around at Bambin Court, but it's especially important to be explosive in the midcourt.
Both defending a smash and intercepting a shot come down to the split second, so even a small delay can result in you losing the rally for the next two lessons.
Technique is still incredibly important, but since these movements are a little simpler, you can focus a bit more on being snappy.
First, let's talk about smash defence.
The stance and split step are very important here.
Typically, we stand in the neutral stance, feet slightly wider than shoulder width apart, with the racket foot slightly ahead.
This is a good general base that allows us to move forward or backwards easily by pushing off a foot.
But we adapted slightly for smash defence.
If you expect that a smash is coming, you change this to a side by side stance with your feet in line with each other.
This does make it hard to move forward or backwards, since we no longer have a way to push off in these directions.
But this is excellent for defending a smash, since you're able to move side by side very effectively, which covers all smash options.
The other thing to note is that you need to get a lot lower than usual.
A good smash will come in fast and low, so starting in a lower position can be the difference between reaching the shuttle and missing it.
The best way to get low is to bring your feet wide apart.
Here, Lee Chong Wei splitstepping for a shot.
You can see he's obviously much wider than shoulder width and he's bending his knees to get down low.
It might feel a bit unnatural to get this low at first, but since it's so important for defending a smash, I need you to force yourself to do this.
Don't worry, it will soon become second nature.
This should get you in a position that looks like this.
Compare this to our neutral stance from earlier and you'll see that it looks very different.
Starting in this stance is much better for defending a smash, but you should only use it when appropriate.
This is for situations where you're confident that it smashes incoming.
For example, after you play a weaklift for most other situations, stick with the neutral stance.
Since we have very little time to react when defending a powerful smash, it's important to start off in the right position.
To begin with, you might think that our base is in the middle of the court, but this is not necessarily true.
Let's say your opponent is smashing from here.
He has the choice to do either a straight smash or a cross court smash.
It's important to note that a straight smash is much faster since it travels a shorter distance as a result.
This is the most threatening to you, so you should move your base slightly towards your opponent's straight smash.
If they smash from here where the straight smash would end up in my forehand corner, I would move slightly to the forehand side.
If they smash from here where the straight smash would go to my backhand corner, I would move slightly to the backhand corner.
Of course, if they're smashing from the middle, then your base position should be in the middle of the court.
For this lesson, let's first consider a situation where my opponent plays a straight smash.
This means I'll be standing close to the side that the smash comes from, so won't have to move as much first the forehand side.
If they're smashing from here, I'd move my base to this point of the court.
I prepare for the smash with a split step and after I see the smash coming in straight, I can defend the shot from the split step.
All I have to do is take a small step towards the shuttle, resembling a lunge to the side.
This movement should feel pretty natural, but the main concern isn't your feet the smash comes down so quickly.
The most important thing to do is to get your racket in position.
The very first thing that you should do when you see the smash incoming is to bring your racket out to the side even before you start moving.
This urgency is going to be especially important as you start to play against better and better players.
Accompany this with a small step and play the shot.
The exact distance to travel depends on where your base is and how far the smashes, but it should never be too far away from you.
If you've already biassed your base towards the straight smash, recover by pushing off the lunging leg and get back into position.
It's the same thing if your opponent is smashing straight from the backhand side of the court.
If the smash is coming from here, you need to move your base slightly to the left.
Again, this puts you in the best position to defend the straight smash.
Start off with a split step with the focus on getting low.
When you see the straight smash incoming, the first thing is to bring your racquet to the shuttle.
Accompany this by taking one step towards the corner lunging however far necessary to reach the shop.
Notice that I'm lunging with my left leg, which is unusual in Bamboaton.
We normally only want to lunge with our racket leg since this is a stronger position to be in.
But in this specific situation, defending a straight smash on the backhand side is one of the few times we lunch with the non racket leg.
Why?
Well, when defending a smash, and especially a straight smash, speed is the number one priority.
It's much quicker to take a small step with my left leg than it is to bring my right leg all the way around.
And since I've already biassed my base towards the left side, a small step with my left leg should be all it takes to get me in position.
The recovery is pretty simple.
Just push off the lunging leg and get back in position.
So as you can see for the forehand and backhand side, defending a straight smash is pretty straightforward.
Pun not intended.
If you're in the correct position, all you have to do is split step to get yourself low and then take one step with the nearest leg.
The main consideration is just to get your racquet in position as soon as possible, even if you move it before your legs.
So while this is pretty simple, what if your opponent decides to play a cross court smash?
Since we position ourselves as a straight smash, this gets a little more complicated.
Obviously, I'm further away from the shuttle now, so one small step won't be enough.
But keep in mind that if your opponent chooses to play a cross court smash, it's significantly slower than a straight smash.
This gives you the extra time needed to get into position.
Let's first have a look at a situation where I'm standing on my forehand side and they smash cross court to my backhand.
The movement starts off just like before with a low and wide split step, and when I see the smash going cross court, I need to react to it just like last time.
The absolute first thing you should do is bring your racket out towards the shuttle.
Your racket is going to be what's actually hitting the shuttle, so it's very important that it gets there in time, even if your feet aren't ready yet.
Then with your feet, take one small step with your left leg and then bring your right leg across and finish with a lunge.

These two simple steps will allow you to get to all cross court smashes, but I really want to emphasise again, that how you move your legs isn't nearly as important as just getting your racket to the shuttle.
As you get better, you often find that you're hitting the shuttle before you finish moving.
For most other corners of the court, that's not a good thing.
But when it comes to defending a smash, not only is this acceptable, it's actually a good thing because it means you're getting to the shuttle as early as possible.
Here you'll see me hitting the shuttle before I've completed my lunch.
If I waited to complete my lunch, the shuttle would have already gone past me.
So focus on getting the racket there early.
After you've played the shot recover by pushing off the lunging leg and get ready for the return.
Now let's have a look at the other side where I'm standing on my backhand side and my opponent smashes cross court to the forehand.
I start off with a split step and again, the first priority is to bring my racket towards the shuttle.
I do this by reaching out and extending my arm in the direction of the smash.
With my feet, I have a further distance to travel, so I take a small chassis step in this direction and then finish by lunging with my right leg.
This should cover enough distance to get me from my base to the shuttle.
Split step, small chassis and then lunge.
After this, I can recover by pushing off my lunging leg and getting back in position for both crosscourt smashes.
I've taught you a movement that will get you all the way to the tram line.
But remember, the exact position of the shuttle will vary a lot depending on how accurate your opponent is.
Unless you're training with Linda Li Chungwei and Kento Momota, you'll find that most cross court smashes land in this sort of an area.
This makes it easier to return as you don't have to travel as far.
It's also easy to adapt.
As long as you get your racket out to the shuttle, which is what I've taught you to prioritise, you'll be able to cover all cross court smashes.
Luckily, you don't have to learn 100 different footwork patterns for these minor variations in placement.
Just bring your racket out to the shuttle and you'll be fine.
To recap.
When defending a smash, it's important to position your base in the same direction that your opponent is smashing.
Lee Chong Wei demonstrates this perfectly here.
Since the straight smash is the most immediate threat, he moves his base towards this side in preparation.
Now, I'm not going to go over each individual situation again because they follow very similar principles.
Each defence movement begins with a split step.
The split step for the defence should be low and wide with both feet in line with each other.
As soon as the opponent hits the smash, your racket needs to be the first thing that moves towards it.
Follow this up by moving your legs towards the shuttle.
Depending on how far away it is, you may need to take one or two steps, but the focus is getting there as quickly as possible.
After playing the shot recovery is simple.
Push off the leading leg back into a standing position and get ready for the next shot.
At the end, I'll include a slow motion of me demonstrating the four standard movements we covered.
Just remember that in a game, you'll need to adapt this on the fly.
Depending on the exact position of a smash, your assignment for this video is to do some drills building up your smash defence.
This movement is fairly simple technically, so the assignment will reflect that on an empty court, stand in a defensive position slightly to the right.
I want you to set up six shuttles, three on this side to represent a straight smash and three on this side to represent a cross court smash.
Keep in mind that you don't need to place these on the tram lines since it's very rare that a smash will be this accurate.
You're going to start off in the middle of the court as if you were defending a smash in a low defensive stance.
Take a split step, then reach out to a corner to knock over one of the shuttles.
When you do this, I don't want you to just lazily knock it over.
Move like you're actually defending a smash.
This means a few things.
You need to get low, you need to move quickly and you need to reach out with the racket first.
Just like you've learned in this lesson.
Just to demonstrate this would be the wrong way of doing things.
Can you see how there's no intensity to get in the right mindset?
When you go through this drill?
Simply pretend that you're defending a smash from Lyndon.
How alert and urgent would that require you to be?
After knocking down the first shuttle, recover back to the middle like I showed you.
Take a moment to reset your position.
No need to rush to pop.
Then repeat this for a shuttle on the other side again.
Moving as quickly as possible.
Recover back to the middle and repeat until you've knocked over all of the shuttles.
You're now going to do this again while standing on the left side of the court.
This replicates a situation where your opponent is smashing from this side of the court.
Otherwise, the drill is the exact same.
Set up three shuttles on each side to replicate the straight and cross court smash.
Then complete the drill by shadowing all of the shots.
Make sure you film yourself doing both these exercises so you can run them through the Swift checklist.
Assess yourself as usual and make any changes if necessary.
Once you pass you've successfully completed this lesson, though I would still recommend that you do a few more repetitions to build up the muscle memory.
You might wonder why I don't have any drills that get you to defend an actual life smash.
And that's just because it's a very difficult drill to feed for.
However, if you do have an experienced feeder or coach to feed, you live smashes, I would recommend it.
But this is completely optional and you'll still get a lot of valuable practise by doing the drill from earlier.
Congratulations, you've now worked your way to the penultimate lesson in this module.
In the next lesson, you're going to learn about mid court interceptions.
But first, here is the slow motion demonstration I promised you earlier.
I'll see you in the next video.
